results.content: Premium Health Features Rolling Out in 2024 At CES, RingConn shared its latest progress in the development of new features, including menstrual cycle tracking and OSAHS (Obstructive Sleep Apnea Hypopnea Syndrome) monitoring.
results.raw_content:
Boasting 24/7 health monitoring with superior comfort and accuracy, the smart ring underlies RingConn's commitment to advancing the intersection of healthcare and technology
LAS VEGAS, Jan. 12, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- RingConn, a leading personal health technology company, left an indelible mark with its beta presentation and received enthusiastic response from attendees at CES 2024. The brand unveiled a comprehensive plan for the upcoming year, emphasizing product development and advanced medical algorithm updates.
The RingConn booth in LVCC North Hall was a buzz of activity, drawing attention from 100+ top-tier media outlets and influencers. This acclaim was paralleled by the interest of the diverse CES audience, many of whom were introduced to the ring, gaining insights into the brand's ambitious vision and discovering the profound impact of its technology on personal health management. The event marked a resounding success, with the revolutionary product capturing attention and receiving acclaim from media representatives, industry analysts, distributors, and consumers.
RingConn's CES Debut Gaining Massive Attention
The CES 2024 exhibition represents a significant milestone for RingConn. Its innovative product garnered the attention of journalists of international top-tier media as well as influencers. Already experienced with a wide array of technology innovations, they were deeply impressed by the ring's form factor, long battery life, and exceptional tracking capabilities. They were amazed to see how RingConn managed to pack advanced sensors into such a small ring, weighing only 3 to 5 grams.
The ring has also attracted distributors from across the globe who recognized the RingConn Smart Ring as a mature form of health tracker and showed strong interest in forming partnerships.
Some of the visitors are one of the RingConn users community, who were once users of smartwatches. For them, the RingConn Smart Ring marks a refreshing approach to health tracking. Compared with wrist-worn devices, it is a much more discreet and lightweight wearable that seamlessly integrates into their everyday lives. Thanks to the 7-day battery life, they no longer need to leave the ring on the charging pad every night.
"The warm support and acclaim we received at CES 2024 are undoubtedly a confidence booster for the team," said Dr. Tony Wu, co-founder of RingConn. "At RingConn, we are not merely providing solutions for personal health management; we are creating the means for users to proactively improve their well-being."
Premium Health Features Rolling Out in 2024
At CES, RingConn shared its latest progress in the development of new features, including menstrual cycle tracking and OSAHS (Obstructive Sleep Apnea Hypopnea Syndrome) monitoring. These two premium features are designed for users with specific needs and are expected to launch for beta testing in Q1 and Q2 of 2024.
Currently, RingConn has already submitted FDA clearance for the ring's pulse oximeter and OSAHS monitoring feature. Therefore, users who suffer from sleep apnea can take preemptive measures before the situation deteriorates. RingConn expects to receive these two FDA clearances by the end of this year. RingConn will establish the ring as a trustworthy device for consumers and even medical professionals. In addition, the team has achieved significant advancements in cuffless blood pressure monitoring, with this feature set to be released in the upcoming year.
Since its global debut, RingConn has provided tailored, professional health services for tens of thousands of users within a year, who have spoken highly of the ring's comprehensive tracking capabilities and the user-friendly accompanying app. Looking ahead, RingConn aims to provide refined solutions to health management through constant hardware and software updates.
About RingConn
Established in 2021, RingConn is a leading personal health technology company dedicated to creating innovative products and services that transform the experience of maintaining personal wellness. Guided by the principle of "Hardware + Software + Services," RingConn aims to become the driver of proactive health management and empower users worldwide by offering a comprehensive and holistic understanding of their well-being.

CES 2024: RingConn’s Smart Ring Is Packed With Features Without A Subscription
Retail Pricing: $279.00
Wearables and AI were two of the most common themes at CES 2024, but what happens when you bring them together? We got to take a closer look at the RingConn Smart Ring at CES Unveiled.
overview
The RingConn Smart Ring is made of Titanium and features a PVD coating to protect it from wear and tear. The Ring is IP68 waterproof and comes in a variety of colors including silver, black and gold. It’s comparable to the size of a thicker wedding band and weighs anywhere from 3 to 5 grams, depending on the size worn.
features
Similar to other wearable brands, RingConn’s ring includes the usual like heart rate monitoring, blood oxygen saturation, skin temperature and movement tracking. It also uses AI to calculate scores for users specific to activity, sleep and stress. This includes calorie estimation, activity intensity tracking, activity scores, sleep metrics and stress tracking. The Ring also integrates with other apps such as Google Fit and Apple Health.
The Ring currently cannot predict menstrual cycles and does not yet offer meditation guidance or mindful breathing, but RingConn says it hopes to have these features soon. All metrics can be viewed from its app, which also features a 24/7 HealthKeeper that gives users actionable insights with the data it collects. RingConn says their app requires no subscription and is free for all users.
The Ring has a 7 day battery life and is charged through its portable charging case and USB-C cable. It’s available now for $279.

AI was the single biggest talking point at CES 2024, with every company delivering some sort of advancement of artificial intelligence into their products. After a strong showing of AI advancements on their lifestyle products at the show, Samsung is now ready to introduce AI into their smartphone division with the newly announced Galaxy S24 series. In fact, the tagline of the unveiling was “Galaxy AI is here” and boy is there a lot to unpack.
It’s a new year and that means it is time for a refresh of products from Xiaomi’s budget brand, Redmi. The Chinese giant announced the new lineup of Redmi Note 13 phones for the 2024 calendar year that includes the standard Note 13, the Note 13 5G, the Note 13 Pro, the Note 13 Pro 5G, and the Note 13 Pro+ 5G. Always the provider of quality value, Redmi has a product for just about every customer in varying price ranges.
At their gigantic CES 2024 booth, we were shocked to see a Nio ES8 on display surrounded by augmented reality glasses. This Chinese EV SUV is a rare sight on American soil as it is currently only sold in China and certain European countries.
At Razer’s booth during CES 2024, the center attraction piece was none other than the upcoming refreshed, Razer Blade 18 laptop. This beauty has Razer’s largest screen size available and will get a bit of a resolution bump in a tradeoff with the refresh rate numbers.
Back in October, Pebble unveiled its all-electric flagship trailer: the Pebble Flow. Featuring an active propulsion assist system and renewable energy capacity, we got the opportunity to check it out at the Pebble booth at CES 2024. Let’s take a closer look.
Wearables and AI were two of the most common themes at CES 2024, but what happens when you bring them together? We got to take a closer look at the RingConn Smart Ring at CES Unveiled.
As dog owners, we take their safety and well being very seriously. That’s why we were highly intriqued when we came across Invoxia’s Minitailz tracker for pets at CES 2024 Unveiled. We spoke briefly with the company to learn more about the self-proclaimed “most advanced health and GPS tracker for dogs” in order to get a better understanding of what makes this a potentially revolutionary pet product.
This year at CES 2024, Shift Robotics provided demonstrations of their Moonwalker shoes. The Moonwalkers are designed for people to travel at running speeds simply by walking at a normal pace. Let’s take a closer look.
This year at CES 2024, Mullen Automotive showcased the Five RS. The Mullen Five RS is a fully electric sport EV crossover based off of its SUV variant, the Mullen Five. The Five RS has dual motors, All-Wheel Drive (AWD) and packs more than 1000 horsepower and over 850 ft lbs of torque thanks to its 800-volt battery architecture. With a max speed of about 200 miles per hour, the Five RS can hit 60 miles per hour in just under two seconds.

CES 2024: RingConn Aims To Revolutionize Fitness Tech With Its Smart Ring
Dr. Hao Wu (Tony), co-founder, RingConn
RingConn, founded in 2021 by Professor Guoxing Wang and his two partners, is taking on Oura with its new Smart Ring. It is the best time to do so because the $147.1 million smart ring market size of 2022 is expected to reach $1,405.1 million by 2032 with a compounded annual growth rate of 25.4%, according to a DataHorizzon Research report.
While we expect more competition in the category in the coming years, it is likely to be defined by people who understand biomedical devices and develop algorithms that work the best for each individual – instead of building generalized products with no actionable insights.
There are plenty of cheap smart wearables that I’ve tested, which lie in the latter category. And it’s a challenge to build something that aims to be a category-defining product – that’s what Professor Wang is focusing on with the RingConn Smart Ring.
This is not his first venture, as he has helped build biomedical devices before. He built the integrated circuits chip for a company called Second Sight that worked on restoring vision for the visually impaired. His expertise lies in circuit design with a Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering from the University of California. I sat down for a conversation with Professor Wang to discuss RingConn, the future of smart rings, and what he aims to deliver with his first product.
Professor Guoxing Wang, founder, RingConn
FC Barcelona Coach Xavi Showed What He Thinks Of Striker In Copa Del Rey Defeat
Real Madrid Boss Ancelotti Would Welcome Saudi Exile Club Legend Back, Reports OK Diario
Chargers Get Their Man In Jim Harbaugh With An Eye-Popping Hire
(.. Continuing our conversation talking about Second Sight) You are a professor now. Why come back to the engineering side of things and establish a personal health technology company?
I worked on this remarkable product and we were successful because after the impression (of the device in the eye) the visually impaired were able to see to an extent. They could see a card on their hand and could walk on the roadside. So that was helpful although the commercial side was not that bright because it was very expensive and it didn’t get the insurance company to back up.
But that was a very crucial experience for me. I’ve been working as a professor for 10 years, so I felt that there’s still some engineering inside myself. I want to make products for people to be able to use them and not just to publish a bunch of papers. So that’s why I started the company RingConn.
When I worked in biomedical I connected circuit research with biological applications. At that time I knew that healthcare devices are very much needed. And that they can be very helpful, especially wearable devices. For example, with the retinal process I developed before it was so rewarding and amazing when people could see. After more than 10 years of research and development for smartwatches, I think it’s time for us to have something better.
For instance, smartwatches aren’t comfortable to be worn at night, and you cannot accurately track various health metrics. That’s where I thought a smart ring could be the answer.
How is the RingConn Smart Ring different from other trackers, like the Oura Ring or the Ultrahuman Ring?
I think we have made a better product in terms of the accuracy of recording vital signs. For example, the heart rate, oxygen saturation level and body temperature are more accurate. Although it’s very difficult for the consumers to sense it, they can verify this by testing other products. It’s not easy but we have tested, and we got more accurate readings.
Second, we have developed a product that can be used for seven days with a single charge. That’s because we have opted for a low-power-consuming electronics design.
The third thing is, we designed a more ergonomic product. When you wear our Smart Ring on your finger, it feels much better because the design is not fully circular but a little bit square on the side. This way, it doesn’t hurt your finger. The bone doesn’t have a circular shape and it’s a bit squarish, so our shell is also of the same design. This fits your finger much more comfortably.
I’ve used a couple of rings with fully circular design, and they felt uncomfortable with bumping against other fingers, so I agree with you on that. However, I’ll have to try the RingConn Smart Ring for myself to see how much more comfortable it is.
Yeah, that’s definitely there and that’s the difference you can feel.
Talking about accuracy, how did you make it more accurate? How is it more accurate than a smartwatch?
Yes. And I think it’s much better than a smartwatch because it fits the finger, so you can get more accurate data from the sensors than on the wrist. The sensors are closer to large blood vessels on a finger rather than on the wrist.
We got it to be more accurate because we put a lot of research effort into this. Others probably don’t really understand how much of a profound impact this could have. This way, we know how to optimize the hardware and algorithms and how to control the sensors for the best readings. We put a lot of emphasis on research from our side as well as a research collaboration with university because as a professor I know the upside of the latter – they can help in some other areas and make the algorithm better.
So I think we sort of combined the best of both academia and development to get the best algorithms on the market so far.
Okay, on the accuracy, how accurate is the data for stress monitoring and sleep?
I think for stress tracking there is no golden standard yet. We developed stress tracking by using the heart rate in this circle (pointing to a part on the index finger), which has hundreds of variations under stress, and we tune the algorithm accordingly. I checked the stress levels for myself and found that they are really accurate because whenever I have meetings my stress level is much higher, like right now [laughs].
If there is no golden standard for it, how do you know it is accurate?
Yeah, there’s no standard that is agreed upon by everyone. But there are some ways to predict that you’re stressed. Like by using the variations of blood flow in the index finger. People in the medical sector have found that the higher your heart rate variability is, the more relaxed you are.
Okay, and despite monitoring 24x7, how did you achieve the 7-day battery life target?
As I said earlier, we put a lot of effort into research. The most important sensor is the PPG sensor, which records the flow of blood inside the blood vessels. And it consumes the most battery. It sends light signals to the blood vessels that travel across your fingers and reflect back to the sensor.
So we focused on finding the best way to optimize it and use the least energy possible. Another way is on the algorithm side. We divide the algorithms inside the firmware side and control the whole system, including the electronics, the wireless transmission and all the calculation of signals to make it more efficient. We developed the best circuit design and the best algorithms.
Is it a proprietary circuit design by RingConn?
Yeah, it’s all developed by ourselves.
There are plenty of fitness trackers that give me scores, like the sleep score or a stress score or throw a lot of numbers at me. But it’s difficult to make sense of all those numbers. Did you work on giving more actionable insights based on these numbers?
For things like stress, as you use it, you realize what induces more stress. For example, I know my stress levels increased during the meeting, and maybe I can be more mindful of it and adjust my lifestyle. Like, I know when I start meetings I should take deeper breaths and relax a little bit. So that’s how I think we use the stress level index.
For the sleep score, I know there’s a lot of sleep-tracking software on the market. But what we are trying to do is calculate the sleep score based on the duration of your sleep and the sleep stages. There’s all sorts of optimal range of your sleep, and our app gives a suggested range for different sleep stages that can help people understand how the sleep score is calculated, so they can make suitable lifestyle changes.
I know some say that a person should sleep a specific x amount of hours through the night but I think that’s not true for everybody because people have different sleeping habits. And people in different age groups sleep differently. In summer, people should sleep for a different duration than in winter. We give users the option to input their best sleep duration and then we calculate the sleep score based on the users’ own judgement.
Does it include naps?
Yes. We give users the option to include sleep targets and naps are included in the target.
“AI” being the buzzword currently, is AI involved in any of this?
Yes. We use the most advanced algorithms yet for the calculation of scores and sleep apnea index calculation.
And is all of this FDA-approved? If not, do you have a timeframe for it?
Not yet. We haven’t received the clearance yet but it is in the works. We expect it to come out by the end of this year.
I see on the website, there are “workout mode” and “sleep apnea” features coming soon. Could you please explain what are these?
(Talking about the workout mode) Yeah, it’s an upcoming feature, and I would let the people wait and find out what it is when it rolls out [laughs].
But let me tell you more about what we’re developing with sleep apnea. It’s a sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts. It is common for people who snore. For some people, it affects the brain because you inhale less oxygen than required. Imagine if you are sleeping every night and you don’t get enough oxygen then it accumulates, which can be very dangerous.
We have developed algorithms that can alert the next morning about how many times you `stopped breathing. If it is too serious, we will suggest you go see a doctor. I think it will be helpful for a lot of people. And it will be released very soon.
Do you see the RingConn Smart Ring making a difference in people’s lives?
Yes. I think people are not satisfied by smartwatches. And I think our Smart Ring can do a much better job because it can get more accurate signals from the finger. Plus, they can do more with it, like detect sleep apnea. We are working on more features and they are coming soon.
I think we can make a big difference because instead of just making sort of a toy like some smart bands or smartwatches, we are offering accurate tracking.
Right now, your app is free but the competitors like Oura and Ultrahuman have paid subscriptions. Do you plan on introducing a paid tier on the RingConn app?
Yes. But for all the basic functions, we are going to keep it free. We’ll explore the paid tier will offer more advanced functions like sleep apnea but we’ll decide based on the driving cost how the market reacts to them. However, all the features currently available are going to be free.
The Smart Ring is your first product. Do you plan on expanding the product line in the future?
At this stage, I think the Smart Ring is such a wonderful product and there are a lot of possibilities to explore. But for now, we are going to focus on this.
RingConn Smart Ring
Adding to this, I talked more about RingConn’s R&D efforts with co-founder Dr. Hao Wu (Tony), who is an Assistant Professor at Shenzhen University, transcript below:
How is the RingConn Smart Ring different from other rings in the market from R&D perspective? I’ve learned that the circuit design has been done in-house How does that help me as a user?
On the RingConn Smart Ring, we have PPG sensors, a skin temperature sensor, and an accelerometer. It’s both the hardware and software that distinguishes it from other wearables.
We designed the circuits ourselves with a very good design of the LED distribution so they can take high-quality measurements. And because of this we could tune the software for better accuracy.
You’re seeking FDA approval and adding sleep apnea detection to the Smart Ring. Does the feature’s rollout depend on getting the approval?
Yes, we have applied for two FDA certifications and one is for sleep apnea detection. Both of them are likely to be issued by the end of this year (2024). And no, we do not need to wait for FDA approval to roll out the feature. It is already available in open beta for our users. We are still testing it.
Do you plan on introducing blood pressure monitoring and blood sugar monitoring?
Two different things. For blood pressure measurement, we have already been researching it for like seven years. We have had some good progress in the last year. We are doing the blood pressure measurements on the ring. As for blood sugar tracking, it’s not easy and we haven’t started any research on it yet.
Do you have the hardware for blood pressure monitoring on this version?
No, we are thinking of introducing it in the next version.
The conversation has been edited and condensed for clarity.
I’m currently using the RingConn Smart Ring for review. My initial impressions are positive, and the flatter sides do make a difference in making it more comfortable.

results.raw_content:
NTT breaks ground on sixth data center in Ashburn, Virginia
The 24MW VA6 due live in early 2024
Construction work has begun on another NTT data center in Northern Virginia.
Clark Construction Group announced this week that it has broken ground on a new data center at NTT’s Ashburn campus in Loudoun County.
The 188,000-square-foot (17,465 sqm) VA6 data center will feature 24MW of critical IT load and will be NTT's sixth data center on-site. VA6 is slated for completion in Q1 2024.
"We are excited to partner with NTT to deliver this critical infrastructure project for the region and help them support their customers' needs," said Louie Sarracino, a vice president at Clark Construction who oversees the company's mission-critical project portfolio. "Data centers are a key sector for Clark, and we look forward to accelerating our growth in the data infrastructure sector in the Mid-Atlantic region and beyond."
NTT currently operates one campus in Northern Virginia which was originally operated under the RagingWire brand; a 78-acre campus in Loudoun County’s Ashburn, with nine planned data centers totaling 224MW of critical IT load and 970,136 sq ft (90,100 sqm) of data floor space.
The company recently announced plans for a new data center campus in Northern Virginia’s Prince William County. It has purchased 103 acres of land in Gainesville and aims to develop a 336MW data center campus there. Spanning four buildings and more than two million square feet (185,800 sqm) of data center space, the Gainesville site will be the company’s largest campus in the US at full build-out. The first two-story building is to open in the second quarter of 2024.
2022 has seen NTT launch facilities in Spain, Indonesia, and India, expand existing locations in the UK and Switzerland, and announce plans for new data centers in Vietnam. Projects in Austria, Germany, and South Africa are ongoing.
NTT has been on an expansion spree across the US. In 2021 the company has launched new data centers in Silicon Valley, Oregon, and Illinois, and announced a new campus in Arizona. Bruno Berti, VP of product management at NTT Global Data Centers, last year told attendees at a DCD event that Covid-19 led to customers trying to reserve “double or triple” their capacity at its data centers.

CES 2024: Best Smart Rings That Might Replace Our Smartwatches Soon
Smart rings are not as popular as smartwatches, but they are slowly progressing to be known in the tech industry. The latest wearable technologies are showcased at CES 2024.
These sleek, finger-adorned devices are primed to take center stage. With features ranging from health tracking to menstrual cycle insights, smart rings will definitely change the way you view the "usual" rings.
The Smart Ring Revolution
The CES 2024 unveiled a myriad of smart rings, and it's surprising to see them along with other products. They are not just accessories; they are multifunctional tools capable of tracking sleep, facilitating NFC payments, and delivering real-time health insights- all without the bulkiness of a smartwatch.
What's more, smart rings offer a discreet alternative to traditional wearables, making them an attractive choice for those who seek subtlety in their tech accessories.
Related Article: CES 2024: This Mila HomeKit-Compatible Solutions Can Improve Air Quality at Home
The Year of the Smart Ring
With the influx of new products and launches, 2024 is poised to be the year when smart rings dominate the wearable tech scene.
Projections from DataHorizzon Research suggest that the smart ring market size will surpass $1 billion by 2032. As more major tech brands express interest, the smart ring market is expected to expand further, with potential entries from industry giants like Samsung adding weight to this growing trend.
Best CES 2024 Smart Rings
RingConn Smart Ring: A Subscription-Free Experience
RingConn's Smart Ring, priced at $279, stands out by eliminating the need for additional subscriptions. With comprehensive health data without extra costs, this smart ring boasts a titanium build, a matte finish, and a one-week battery life.
The package includes a portable charging case that can power the ring for 150 days.
Amazfit Helio Ring: Streamlined Health Data Management
Amazfit's Helio Ring simplifies sleep and health data management by consolidating all information into one app.
Designed to work independently, this smart ring syncs seamlessly with the Zepp app on your smartphone, eliminating the necessity for a smartwatch.
Ideal for those deeply entrenched in the wearable ecosystem, the Helio Ring offers a holistic approach to health tracking.
Movano Evie Ring: A Women-Focused Breakthrough
Movano's Evie Ring, an honoree at CES 2024, stands out as the first women-focused smart ring. Pioneering women-specific data paired with an AI engine, the Evie Ring provides predictive insights into menstrual health, mood, sleep, and physical activity.
With the unique Daily Summary feature, users can quickly grasp activity and recovery metrics without the need for additional subscriptions, making it an innovative and user-friendly choice priced at $269.
For the years to come, smart rings will be identified under the same classification as smartwatches. They are obviously underrated, at least for now. Still, the future of wearables is unfolding at our fingertips.

ZDNET's recommendations are based on many hours of testing, research, and comparison shopping. ZDNET's editorial team writes on behalf of you, our reader. Our goal is to deliver the most accurate information and the most knowledgeable advice possible in order to help you make smarter buying decisions on tech gear and a wide array of products and services. Our editors
thoroughly review and fact-check every article to ensure that our content meets the highest standards. If we have made an error or published misleading information, we will correct or clarify the article. If you see inaccuracies in our content, please report the mistake via this form.
The best smart rings we saw at CES 2024
It's been a long time coming, but smart rings are slowly yet surely gaining mainstream popularity and interest. Take the rings unveiled at this year's CES, the tech industry's largest consumer technology convention of the year: We saw rings that track your menstrual cycle and use AI to offer relevant health insights, rings that hone in on athletic recovery data, and rings that make tracking health information more simple and efficient.
Also: CES 2024: What's next in tech
Special Feature
Best of CES 2024
ZDNET sorts through the wave of CES news and announcements to identify innovations that will make the most impact on professionals. Learn about the newest products and trends that transform the future of work and life.
Smart rings are the future wrapped around your finger: They can track your sleep, function as a form of NFC payment, and provide by-the-minute health insights without the bulkiness and additional screen of a smartwatch. Plus, they're far more discreet than other wearables.
"Smart rings offer an opportunity to seamlessly track one's health with a small, screenless form factor," says Stacy Salvi, vice president of product and strategy at Movano Health, makers of the Evie smart ring. "Consumers want an easy way to wear a device for an extended period without having to charge daily, which is the case with many smart watches. Because there is no screen on a ring, data is viewed exclusively on an app, which has more real estate to communicate the critical metrics in an engaging and fun way while also being informative."
With all these new products unveiling and launching, 2024 is ramping up to be the year of the smart ring. And we're just getting started: The smart ring market size is expected to grow to an over $1 billion industry by 2032, according to a recent report by DataHorizzon Research. Expect more smart rings to hit the market this year and next, with larger tech brands (did we see that Samsung might be entering the smart ring race with a new Galaxy Ring?) throwing their hat in the ring -- pun intended.
Also: The best smart rings
I've rounded up the most notable smart rings on display at CES that ZDNET's team got to check out, and that are worthy of your attention this year. Some are available to buy now, and some are available for purchase later this year.
The top smart rings of CES
Movano Evie Ring
We've been excited about the Evie Ring since last year, when Movano unveiled its product concept at CES 2023. The Evie Ring is the first women-focused smart ring that uses the health data it tracks to offer up a holistic view of overall health and wellness -- and it just earned a 2024 CES Innovation Honoree Award.
What differentiates the Evie Ring from other smart rings on the market is its women-specific data that pairs with an AI engine to offer predictive insights into a women's menstrual health, mood, sleep, physical activity, and more. Plus, the ring includes a notable smart metric, called Daily Summary, which offers up an at-a-glance activity and recovery graphic for succinct health data visualization (so you can spend less time parsing rogue graphs together and more time digging into health solutions with tangible results).
Also: This women's smart health ring uses AI to analyze menstrual and sleep data
No additional subscription nor membership is necessary with this $269 ring. Get the smart ring in silver, gold, or rose gold. The product is expected to ship later this month.
RingConn Smart Ring
Most smart rings come with a subscription you have to buy in addition to the already-expensive smart ring itself. The subscriptions, like the Oura Ring membership, tend to offer supplementary insights on sleep data, personalized health insights, and a glance at your health trends over time.
Like the Evie Ring, RingConn's smart ring sidesteps the subscriptions and offers you comprehensive health data without the additional cost of a subscription. At $279, RingConn's Smart Ring comes in Moonlit Silver, Midnight Black, and Pale Gold, with a titanium build and a matte finish. Along with a one-week battery life, the ring also comes with a portable charging case that can keep your ring powered for up to 150 days.
Also: RingConn takes on Oura with an impressive subscription-free smart ring
ZDNET contributing writer Matt Miller got his hands on the RingConn smart ring, and praised it for its substantial battery life and powerful smartphone app.
Amazfit Helio Ring
With Amazfit's Helio Ring, all your sleep and health data is stored in one app -- no smartwatch necessary. "When you wake up, you can put on the watch while wearing the ring -- or not -- and all of your health, wellness, and sports activity data will be synced and available in the Zepp app (formerly Amazfit) on your smartphone,"ZDNET contributing writer Matt Miller reported.
Using a smart watch and the ring together is the real deal, since a watch can better measure activities and track your exercise through GPS, while the ring can monitor your sleep and resting modes. For these reasons, the ring seems optimal for someone who's already plugged into the wearable ecosystem and looking to wear both a watch and a ring for health data tracking.
Also: One ring, one app: Amazfit's new smart ring integrates sleep and fitness data
The ring will launch with ring sizes 10 and 12, with more ring sizes and colors coming later this year.
Other smart rings to watch
Elevate meditation
YogiFi Ring
Track your mind, body, and breath with this smart ring made for yogis. The ring tracks your yoga asanas, meditation sessions, and sleep.
Another smart ring
Dcare Ring
Learn more about your heart health, sleep, and steps with this $200 smart ring.
